In a number of cases involving application of the death penalty , ORG observed that if the due process guarantees in LAW were violated , a sentence of death which was carried out would not be in conformity with LAW which delineates the circumstances when it is permissible to give effect to the death penalty .
CARDINAL . In the case of PERSON v. GPE ( no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) , the ORG stated as follows :

“ [ T]he imposition of a sentence of death upon the conclusion of a trial in which the provisions of the LAW have not been respected constitutes ... a violation of article CARDINAL of the LAW . As the ORG noted in its general comment CARDINAL ) , the provision that a sentence of death may be imposed only in accordance with the law and not contrary to the provisions of the LAW implies that ' the procedural guarantees therein prescribed must be observed , including the right to a fair hearing by an independent tribunal , the presumption of innocence , the minimum guarantees for the defence , and the right to review by a higher tribunal ' . ”

CARDINAL . Similar observations were made by ORG in the case of PERSON v. GPE ( Communication no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , DATE , ORG . ORG . no . DATE , [ A/CARDINAL/CARDINAL ] , at DATE ] ) ) and PERSON v. GPE ( Communication no . CARDINAL , ORG . CCPR / C/CARDINAL/D/CARDINAL/CARDINAL [ DATE ] ) .

CARDINAL . In an Advisory Opinion on “ The right to information on consular assistance in the framework of the guarantees of due process of law ” ( Advisory Opinion OC-CARDINAL/CARDINAL of DATE ) ORG examined the implication of the guarantees of a fair procedure with LAW , which permitted the death penalty in certain circumstances . It stated :

“ CARDINAL . It might be useful to recall that in a previous examination of LAW to the Death Penalty , Advisory Opinion OC-CARDINAL/CARDINAL of DATE , Series A No . CARDINAL ) the ORG observed that the application and imposition of capital punishment are governed by the principle that ' [ n]o one shall be arbitrarily deprived of his life ' . Both LAW require strict observance of legal procedure and limit application of this penalty to ' the most serious crimes ' . In both instruments , therefore , there is a marked tendency toward restricting application of the death penalty and ultimately abolishing it .

CARDINAL . This tendency , evident in other inter - NORP and universal instruments , translates into the internationally recognised principle whereby those GPE that still have the death penalty must , without exception , exercise the most rigorous control for observance of judicial guarantees in these cases . It is obvious that the obligation to observe the right to information becomes all the more imperative here , given the exceptionally grave and irreparable nature of the penalty that one sentenced to death could receive . If the due process of law , with all its rights and guarantees , must be respected regardless of the circumstances , then its observance becomes all the more important when that supreme entitlement that every human rights treaty and declaration recognises and protects is at stake : human life .

CARDINAL . NORP Because execution of the death penalty is irreversible , the strictest and most rigorous enforcement of judicial guarantees is required of the State so that those guarantees are not violated and a human life not arbitrarily taken as a result . ”
CARDINAL . In its GPE , PERSON and PERSON and GPE judgment of DATE , ORG stated :

“ Taking into account the exceptionally serious and irreparable nature of the death penalty , the observance of due process , with its bundle of rights and guarantees , becomes all the more important when human life is at stake ” ( at § MONEY ) .
